qa_list.question: What is the main point of the text?
qa_list.answer: The text discusses the effectiveness of a partial selection scheme in reducing labeling costs in different querying methods for information extraction tasks.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What is the benefit of the partial selection scheme mentioned in the text?
qa_list.answer: The partial selection scheme requires lower labeling costs than full annotation to reach the upper bound.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What does the text suggest about combining the method with more complex acquisition functions?
qa_list.answer: The text suggests that it would be interesting to explore combining the method with more complex acquisition functions, such as those considering representativeness.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. qa_list.answer: Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: How do the relation extraction results compare between PA and FA in the text?
qa_list.answer: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What is the cost measurement difference between FA relation extraction and PA in the text?
qa_list.answer: FA relation extraction cost is measured by two times the annotated entities, while PA counts the number of queried relations.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What is considered when calculating sentence uncertainty in the text?
qa_list.answer: The high weight (β) of the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments) is considered when calculating sentence uncertainty.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What approach does the text suggest to enhance both sub-tasks in the experiments?
qa_list.answer: The text suggests exploring better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, possibly with an adaptive combination scheme.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What does Figure 10 show in the text?
qa_list.answer: Figure 10 shows the results of the extraction of entity mentions and relations for the relation extraction task on ACE05.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� qa_list.question: What is the focus of some mention extraction results in the text?
qa_list.answer: Some mention extraction results show less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline, possibly due to a focus on the second sub-task for relations.
qa_list.ref_chunk: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). ����� ACE05.

doc_text: Figure 8 and 7, respectively. Generally, there are no large differ- ences between the adopted querying methods and the margin-based method can obtain the overall best results. Notice that regardless of the adopted acquisition function, we can see the effectiveness of our partial selection scheme: it requires lower labeling cost than full annotation to reach the upper bound. This shows that our method is extensible to different AL querying methods and it will be in- teresting to explore the combination of our method with more complex and advanced acquisition func- tions, such as those considering representativeness. D.2 IE Experiments In this section, we present more results of the IE experiments. First, Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task. The overall trends are very similar to those in NER: PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost. In Figure 10, we show the results for mention and relation extractions. In the ACE dataset, relations are very sparsely annotated, and around 97% of the entities are linked with less or equal to two rela- tions. Considering this fact, we measure the cost of FA relation extraction by two times the anno- tated entities, while PA still counts the number of the queried relations. The relation results are sim- ilar to the patterns for event argument extraction, showing the benefits of selecting and annotating with partial sub-structures. Notice that in some of the mention extraction results, there seems to be less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline. This may be due to our focus on the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments), directly reflected by its high weight (β) in calculating sentence uncertainty. It will be interesting to explore better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, probably with an adaptive combination scheme (Roth and Small, 2008). �����
